If there are  'official' names for these features, I'd love to know. topic.title: Suggestion: better explanation of space limits and errors
topic.body:
My problems and confusion with ZeroTorrent are down to the issue of "space" apparently. So here's a recap of the current situation, followed by a proposal for improvement for 0net sites with user-generated content (e.g. ZeroTalk, ZeroMe, blog comments) that I feel would really help new users like me.

## Current
+ The idea of "space" (i.e. limits for user-generated content on a site) is never really explained anywhere in ZeroNet documentation or on the sites themselves (as far as I can tell).
+ There is some tiny text ("USED...") near comment boxes that gives unexplained info.
+ That tiny text then gives a hint at the issue... ***if*** you happen to mouse over it.
+ The error messages when a user hits their limit are meaningless *and* contradictory.
> **! Content signing failed**.
> Include too large 6510676B >2000000B

and

> **¡ File upload success**

So... success? or failure? Which is it??? And "Include too large" is some kind of Google Translate error. And, in contrast to everywhere else on 0net, these messages uses bytes in huge strings of digits.

## Proposal
+ Post a brief explanation of space limits for user-generated content in the ZeroNet documentation (and elsewhere, e.g. wiki).
+ The presence of mouseover text by "USED..." should indicated by some kind of text or symbol, e.g. a coloured question mark, or "Info".
+ When a person posts something (or does anything that uses up their allowed space), show a popup message when they click "Submit/Upload/Post":
> *All your topics, comments, votes and uploads here deduct from your total space on this site, which is [...KB].*

And provide a checkbox:
> *Do not show this message again.*

+ When a person goes over their limit for a site, error messages needs to:
++ be meaningful not only to the developer but to the person directly affected, i.e. the user
++ not contradict each other
++ give the user an idea how to proceed

E.g.

> **! Failed to publish content**
> You have gone over your total allowed space for your content on this site. Either delete some or contact the site admin to increase your limit.
> Your content=127KB. Limit=100KB.

topic.title: What do you think about having a ZeroArchive to save websites?
topic.body:
+ [Wikipedia - Web archiving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_archiving)

ZeroNet is already its own preservation system, but what about having something on 0net like the Wayback Machine (a.k.a. Internet Archive) or [Archive.today](https://archive.today/) for clearnet sites, allowing easy archiving of clearnet webpages because:
+ the content might change, disappear or be behind a paywall
+ the content might be blocked on clearnet in certain locations

Maybe have hubs, so that people don't have to download the entire thing. Hubs based on things like:
+ language
+ content type

Features that would be nice:
+ set up automated saving of pages
+ a [bookmarklet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bookmarklet) or browser extension to instantly archive the page you're viewing

Obviously there would need to be protection against spam & other abuse.

---

I've been dabbling in my own incompetent way, [saving a newspaper blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Post:4:UK+Newspapers+Front+Pages+-+Sunday+24th+March+2019) (whose images of newspaper front pages disappear after one day) in [mhtml](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553562592) & [structured html](https://github.com/gildas-lormeau/SingleFile) and posting to ZeroUp Unlimited. I've also been looking at [Page Cache Archiver](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/archiver-menu/) which, along with a list of archiving websites already built-in, allows saving to a custom archive (but I have no idea how to make that work).

But it would be great if there was a dedicated 0net solution, e.g. archive zite + tools (script / bookmarklet / whatever).

topic.title: WebP images on ZeroNet won't open, but fine on clearnet
topic.body:
I noticed in [my experiment with WebP](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:20:Experimenting+with+images:+WebP) that links to WebP images would download, instead of just opening in my browser. Even right-clicking and choosing "Open image in new tab" and even "Image properties" results in a download dialog box.

Example WebP on ZeroNet: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882551-stig.revealed.webp

I thought it was an issue specific to my browser (Vivaldi) and how it treats the WebP format.

But then I tried the WebPs [on this clearnet site](https://developers.google.com/speed/webp/gallery1).

Example WebP on clearnet:
https://www.gstatic.com/webp/gallery/1.sm.webp

And they worked. They opened in Vivaldi just fine.

I then tested in Chrome and Firefox. Same thing: in all browsers, I can open the clearnet WebPs just fine, but the ZeroNet WebPs will only download.

How can we fix this?

topic.title: Visitors having problems with optional files and comments on my ZeroBlog
topic.body:
The blog: [The Papers](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx/)

Issues pointed out in the comment thread on [this ZeroMe post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1560005799)

The blog is my amateur attempt at archiving daily posts (as all-in-one html files) showing newspaper front pages, before they get erased by the original website after 24 hours. These posts contain several large images (each all-in-one html file is between 2.5MB and 4.5MB) and the total is always increasing (new post every day); this folder is currently at 193MB after only 6 weeks of posts.

Because of those factors, I made the files optional (by putting the files in a folder called **/data/papers** and making that folder optional in my blog's **content.json**). I think making the files non-optional would not be ideal, as first time visitors would be confronted with a demand for a huge amount of space, and and existing peers would be nagged with constant requests to increase site size limit as the archive grows.

But now visitors are having difficulty getting the files ("`download failed`"), even though I'm online 24/7 (port opened, Tor available, connected to multiple trackers).

Another issue, maybe related: visitors can't make comments on the blog, getting `File write error: [object Object]`. When I try to post a comment, I get `Content publish failed`.

Any ideas / suggestions how to deal with these issues? Thanks.

It's like you've just expanded your internet to include another piece: now with ZeroNet installed, you can also surf ZeroNet sites and download ZeroNet files. You can also make your own ZeroNet site (quickly & easily) without having to worry about finding (and paying) a host, because just by having ZeroNet turned on, we are all helping each other out with hosting and getting sites and files: we don't depend on companies doing it for us (for a price: either our money or our privacy). 

As a bonus, you can (with a few simple steps) do all this in a way that can't be blocked or tracked by third parties like governments, big data marketing companies etc.

That at least is my summary, but I'm also new here. Welcome!

Well, I've found out *a little* more on `zero://` if anyone's interested.
1. Having that bit on the front is called a protocol.
2. Having browsers accept that protocol natively is not currently supported. One needs to get a request accepted by the browser makers.
3. As of [this post by Binchan with more info](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:71:zero://), the protocol is not yet accepted by Firefox but (I think) some of the 0net developers have petitioned Mozilla/FF.

1548909076_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf.body:
What kind of tool you need depends on what you want to do.
* Do you want the software to translate it all for you? Then you're looking for **machine translation** (MT).
See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_translation and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_machine_translation_applications
* Do you want the software to help you translate (make it easier, quicker etc)? Then you're looking for **computer-aided translation (CAT), machine-assisted translation (MAT)**, various other names etc.
See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_translation and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_computer-assisted_translation_tools

Machine translation can be useful when you don't know one of the languages at all. But then you can't be sure of the quality of the results. I'm afraid I don't know anything about offline Linux MT so try the links above.

Computer-assisted translation can be useful when you know both the source and destination language. It can take care of a lot of the legwork for you, and then you verify and polish it up.

E.g. the last time I did translation work with free-libre open source software, it was word processor documents where I knew both the source and destination languages. I used OpenOffice.org and a plug-in called [Anaphraseus](http://anaphraseus.sourceforge.net/), which is a type of CAT software called a translation memory (TM).I also used [OmegaT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OmegaT). As I translated the document, the TM learned how I had translated words and phrases earlier on the document (and in previous documents) and then offered suggestions when encountering those phrases later in the document. Sort of like predictive text for translations, which can really speed it up.

TLDR:
+ For translating files, have a look at https://www.matecat.com/ , which is online but also offers [self-installation](https://www.matecat.com/installation-guide/). See also [Getting Started with MateCat](https://www.matecat.com/support/introducing-matecat/getting-started-matecat/) and the [FAQ](https://www.matecat.com/faq/).
+ For inputting text snippets (like Google Translate), have a look at http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/Apertium_Simpleton_UI or regular [Apertium](http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/Installation) (but be careful about [the language pairings available](http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/List_of_language_pairs) e.g. it seems it can translate between English and Kazakh but not directly between English and French). (For an online experience with Apertium, forget the official online test drive and try https://apertiumtrad.tuxfamily.org/ and choose "Text Translation" which allows you choose a bridge language to expand the translation possibilities, e.g. English to Spanish to French.)

---
I offer here some more of the technical jargon & info, which might help in searches on the subject.

In language and translation, those kinds of databases are called ***corpora*** (plural) / ***corpus*** (singular), and a pair of cross-referenced corpora are called parallel corpora (and multiply for every combination of languages conceivable). E.g. one parallel corpus for Greek and Latin and Hebrew (for, say, biblical scholarship), a different one for English and Greek, yet another for English and Latin etc.

+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_corpus
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpora_in_Translation_Studies
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_text

IIRC the EU (which needs to produce documents in all official languages) is a major source of parallel corpora and translations memories based on them. I believe those are mainly useful for assisting human translators (i.e. computer-assisted translation) translate documents, but I'm guessing from your link that you're looking for quick full machine translation of text snippets like Google Translate.

NOTE 1: Downloading the corpora & other files for every single language (***and*** every single possible language pairing) out there would be a massive undertaking, so you would probably need to narrow your search down to the specific languages (& language pairings) you need.
NOTE 2: Sometimes you might have to choose a ***bridge language***. I.e. To get from language A to language B, the software might have to go through language C. E.g. at [this online instance of Apertium](https://apertiumtrad.tuxfamily.org/tradtexte.php), to translate from English to French (for which [Apertium](https://github.com/apertium/apertium) does not have a completed validated pairing yet), you have to choose either Spanish or Catalan as a bridge language to get a result.
NOTE 3: the language pairings are not always bidirectional: sometimes a corpus or machine translation engine is suitable for translating from language A to language B, but not for going from language B to Language A.

It seems there is at least one open source machine translation engine & service mainly based on EU corpora, but also providing a few pairings between English and non-EU languages.
+ https://www.modernmt.eu/
+ https://github.com/ModernMT/MMT
+ https://github.com/ModernMT/MMT/wiki

It seems more like an advanced CAT (a tool to aid someone who knows both the source and target languages), but I'm not sure. [This video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGUqGddCZGI) implies that ModernMT can be used as a backend MT engine inside other tools like **MateCat** which is an open source CAT web application that helps you translate document files (e.g. .docx) that offers two possibilities:
1. use their hosted online MateCat service at https://www.matecat.com/ (which offers a confidential option)(choosing ModernMT as an engine there requires payment, but there are other possibilities, e.g. your own TM)
2. [install your own MateCat instance on your computer](https://www.matecat.com/installation-guide/) along with your own instance of an MT engine or **TM** (translation memory), like your own free installation of ModernMT

For the hosted online service, see [Getting Started with MateCat](https://www.matecat.com/support/introducing-matecat/getting-started-matecat/).
> MateCat already provides matches from a public translation memory with over 12 billion words and free machine translation. You can also create private translation memories for better reuse of your translations and for confidential projects (click on Settings to add your personal TM).

From the [FAQ](https://www.matecat.com/faq/) for their online service:
> **How private are my translations and translation memories?**
> To guarantee the confidentiality of your translations, use a private TM when creating your project in MateCat, and make sure that the “Update” checkbox closed to the private TM key  is selected. In doing so you can be safe that your translated segments are stored only inside your private TM. Only the person who has created the private TM has access to it (the “owner”) and its content will not be shared with anyone else as opposed to the public TM which is available to all MateCat users. There will still be suggestions from the public TM, but your segments will not be saved in it.

> [leftside](#comment_646_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): For the time being we could use tor-browser to visit google translate site.No IP trace.

I think this is partly covered in our ZeroMe thread, but the problem with Google Translate isn't just about IP address.
+ What you ask Google to translate could include identifying or personal data. 
+ The URL for the Google Translate results includes the full text of what was translated (including any identifying or personal data).
+ The URL can be read/intercepted by third parties, including ISPs and browser extensions.
+ Third parties, including ISPs and browser extensions, sell data dumps of billions of visited URLs to... basically anyone.
+ [That video](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1549142235) demonstrated identifying people not by IP address ***but just by analyzing visited URLs***.

So in the video, the researchers identified a policeman (a ***cybersecurity*** policeman!!) by seeing the URL of a Google Translate page of an e-mail he was writing that included his name. And using basic statistical techniques, they were also able to determine all the other URLs he visited in the data dump they bought (in fact they didn't even have to buy the data dump; a web marketing company gave it to them as a free sample) and find out much more about him.

@quantumworld: You're welcome. Just remember that integrating a translator into 0net puts you back in the cloud and requires trust of the provider. But if something like Apertium can be online on clearweb, maybe it's possible on 0net. Although I don't know how it would work with the backend corpora in that scenario, as they would require gigabytes of space.

I've done a quick test of Apertium Simpleton UI, posted a review on my blog:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:9:New+blog+post

1551567748_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf.body:
**Situation: there's a clearnet page or article about a problem that affects clearnet but not Zeronet.** E.g.
+ censorship
+ linkrot / site going offline
+ takedowns, especially bogus automated takedowns
+ geoblocking
+ etc.

**Actions:**
+ find and mirror the affected content on Zeronet and provide a Zeronet link to it in the news article's comments
+ or link to an already existing mirror on Zeronet
+ resist the temptation to get too "evangelistic". Just provide a zeronet link (as though it's the most normal thing in the world) to the content and mention in passing that it's not affected by the problem in the article.
+ If another commenter asks/is confused by a Zeronet link, provide just one or two short sentences about Zeronet (e.g. "It's decentralized, so they can't block it", "Once you've installed Zeronet, you can view it in your regular browser") and link to a Zeronet beginner's guide available on clearnet.
+ prepare to overcome objections. Example objection: "Why not just use Tor?" Example response: "Tor's fine, but you can do a lot more with Zeronet. Like make your own unblockable, decentralized site in minutes with no server required. And anyway Zeronet can run over Tor."
+ other?

**Example situation:**
+ News article about a clearnet site constantly having to change its domain name to avoid blocking - [TorrentFreak - Pirate Proxy ‘Unblocked’ Fights Censors With 38th Domain Name](https://torrentfreak.com/pirate-proxy-unblocked-fights-censors-with-38th-domain-name-190228/)

**Example action:**
+ Post a comment on that article like:
> The Unblocked mirror on Zeronet working fine for me http://127.0.0.1:43110/171amnchKeBrXnDVooTMKhHH9npTu1hRWj

1551558721_1CVzc6Q13qL6MskGL9Ni7os6Gjfor.body:
I was drafting a (huge, bloated) bl0g article about this but you've pre-empted me :), inspired by [Bitzi / Bitpedia](http://web.archive.org/web/20131209222254/http://bitzi.com/bitpedia/), which was an online media hash database of user submissions ([examples](https://web.archive.org/web/20091211184946/http://bitzi.com:80/stat/bitprints_week_100)) active in the 2000s, from the people who invented the Magnet URI.

They offered a tool called Bitcollider (open source and [still on Sourceforge](https://sourceforge.net/projects/bitcollider/)) that automated the process:
1. You just dragged a file onto Bitcollider, which then automatically extracted / produced a range of metadata: file size, resolution, bitrate etc as well as various checksums (inc. P2P-specific ones, if you had those apps installed).
2. Bitcollider then automatically opened a Bitpedia submission page in your browser, with fields like File Name and metadata already filled in.
3. Users could add a little more, like a quality rating out of 10, tags, then click submit. The file then got its own page on Bitpedia with all the info, checksums and clickable links (Magnet, ed2k etc).

It was quick and easy. Bitcollider doesn't work any more, of course, as the Bitpedia website no longer exists, but if something like that could be made for a database on Zeronet (even hacking original BitCollider), that would be great. I was even wondering if using a [Bitzi datadump](https://old.datahub.io/dataset/bitzi) to "kickstart" / populate a hash database here on Zeronet would be useful, so that it wouldn't start off empty. But people would probably be pissed off if there were loads of hashes for files that simply weren't available on Zeronet.

By the way, [here's an example from the old Bitpedia I tried out a month ago](http://web.archive.org/web/20130913032141/http://bitzi.com:80/lookup/ADE2HDOI75PZB2NR6CVB7BEJJL4C37TW
) to see what would happen and:
+ Good news: The file *Transformers[2007]DvDrip[Eng]-aXXo.avi* started downloading almost immediately, so this still works!
+ Bad news: The file *Transformers[2007]DvDrip[Eng]-aXXo.avi* started downloading almost immediately, so... I was getting a really crappy movie! :)

I had to use Shareaza, which found a source on its own G2 (Gnutella 2) p2p filesharing network. Regular hashes are/were incompatible with BitTorrent IIRC, which I think was a contributing factor in the demise of Bitpedia.

@advocatusdiaboli: I don't think I would ever finish it (as it got too huge and too much about importing the out-of-date Bitzi database) but I've put up the draft here for you: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:12:Build+a+database+of+media+metadata+on+ZeroNet

1555302116_1FUAYb5srAuXuzNsKKtbd6cpNfQbE.body:
You can post/host torrents (i.e. files that end in `.torrent`) on:
+ torrent sites that allow user submission, like [ZeroTorrent](http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit/)
+ file sharing/upload sites, like [ZeroUp Unlimited](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/)
+ your own site, e.g. clone a ZeroBlog and host torrents there

You can post Bittorrent magnet links:
+ torrent sites that allow user submission of magnet links, like ZeroTorrent or [ZeroMagnets](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1omkDtXPXekU2EtyMgcqFUAqMVgnv1VDN/)
+ anywhere that you can post text, e.g.
+ + forums like this, Millchan etc
+ + your own site. Here's an example on my blog: [klu9's media share - Serbuan Maut (The Raid)](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Post:29:Serbuan+Maut+(The+Raid%29) (near bottom of page, marked "Magnet download")
+ + in comments on other people's blogs etc.

If posting to somewhere like ZeroTorrent, be aware that every user has a space limit on how much content they can post there (to prevent spamming/overload). I didn't understand that at first and I uploaded some uncompressed screenshots, using up all my space and preventing any new posts I make there being seen by other people (although I can see them myself).

1555521255_1ME9gwj9Exp9cBbuSxxr1mEiySEjm.body:
Am I wrong or can .cbz extension just be changed to .zip and it still works?
EDIT: someone did it with .cbr & IFS: http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz2_1Mx5xcSVsv8mdsXtKwBPD8X1SEfzN2VR5u_item_6+type:archive

@squarezero: I have a bit of a soft spot for the DJVU format (I used to use it to convert JPG scans of textbooks into files that were a fraction of the size *and* used far less RAM when viewing), but I didn't realize comics were being shared in it. A quick search for 'djvu' on IFS and Torrentz2 doesn't turn up any comics results (at least not in a language I read; half the results were in Cyrillic). Can you share any?

@squarezero: Recently been playing around with WebP (which doesn't produce artifacts around text at high compression rates the way JPG does), and I got quite good results converting a 1.6MB comic page JPG to 590KB WebP. That was me doing things manually with an image viewer/editor, but then I found this tool:
+ http://tomeko.net/software/CbxConverter/ (latest version at bottom of page)

At default settings (no resize; quality: 75), it reduced [this 60MB CBR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz2_1Mx5xcSVsv8mdsXtKwBPD8X1SEfzN2VR5u_item_6+type:archive) to a 30MB CBZ.
At quality setting 50, it reduced it 21MB. And I absolutely could not tell the difference between the original and the conversion.

I also did a version at quality 50 and resized to 66% (ideal would have been 74-75%, but CbxConverter's resizing options are limited to just a selection of percentages: 66, 50, 33, 25). It came in at just 12MB. It's only a little under my screen width and certain parts actually look *better* compared to the full-size original when that's adjusted to fit my screen width.

An online conversion to DJVU (which didn't allow any quality settings) made the 1.6MB JPG into a 1.1 MB DJVU. It would be great if there was an offline tool like CbxConverter but for DJVU.

Saw an interesting comment in this post: [Technical details on the recent Firefox add-on outage](https://www.osnews.com/story/129992/technical-details-on-the-recent-firefox-add-on-outage/)

**Comment by Alfman**
> I find it a bit ironic that with all the criticism of backdoors, politicians are lashing out at foreign companies, meanwhile western companies like mozilla are able to use their own backdoors to remotely modify user settings.

> > *Ironically, the solution to this problem is a special type of add-on called a system add-on (SAO). In order to let us do research studies, we have developed a system called Normandy which lets us serve SAOs to Firefox users. Those SAOs automatically execute on the user’s browser and while they are usually used for running experiments, they also have extensive access to Firefox internal APIs. Important for this case, they can add new certificates to the certificate database that Firefox uses to verify add-ons.*

> 
> I’m not alleging any malicious intent here, but I’m bothered by some of the political and corporate hypocrisy. Consider that mozilla’s chief legal and business officer has previously said this about backdoors:

> http://time.com/4263121/apple-fbi-backdoor/

> > *We also need to understand that any backdoors that companies are asked to build are doors that can be opened, not just by law enforcement, but by others that want to do harm roaming the Web.*

> 
> There is just no “safe” backdoor. You are either safe or you are not.

> If they want to defend their backdoor (which has much deeper local access than a regular extension) as a useful tool for legitimate functions, I’ll begrudgingly say I understand their reasoning. If they want to say there is no safe backdoor, I can understand that too. However the hypocrisy is what I don’t have much tolerance for. On the one hand they tell owners we can no longer install our own extensions for our own safety, and yet on the other hand they wrote their own remote access backdoors for our machines.

> I’ll give them the benefit of doubt regarding non-malicious intent, but why should they be entitled to higher access than the owners? And why, if they are so concerned about iphone backdoors being accessed by court mandate, do they place their own users at risk through their own low level backdoors? It’s do as we say, not as we do.

> Sorry about the rant, I’m just venting some of my frustrations.

@kropptyler: ZeroFun already allows videos, as well as other space-efficient alternatives to animated GIFs, like animated WebP ([example](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ZGagD38ypjSoUrpNEGaPFmAMKFcdud7C/?post=131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs_1557497281929), 36KB).
Do you mean it should *ban* animated GIFs and only allow other formats instead? If so, I think that could be useful: save space and get people to transition away from bloated animated GIFs.

Re GIFs, the latest post (Charge Turbine) is a 14-second animated GIF that weighs in at **21.5MB**. The homepage took forever to load (about 15-20 minutes before the loading bar at top of page disappeared).

Using WebM Converter (as detailed [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:14:Experimenting+with+alternatives+to+GIFs,+part+1)), I turned that GIF into a WebM video that was *merely* 4.3MB. I suspect if someone was starting from the original video (and not video > GIF > video) and/or knew more about encoding than me, they'd probably get an even better file size.

I think this supports the idea that animated GIFs should not be allowed, given the way ZeroNet works.

@xcape2net:

Every computer running ZeroNet is a peer. Trackers are specific computers that peers connect to, and which help the peers find each other so that the peers can communicate and share content.

If you are connected to 0 trackers, you won't be able to connect to anyone else and can't send or receive content. If you are connected to lots of trackers, you will find more peers and be more likely to successfully find, send and receive ZeroNet content. (And I'm not sure but maybe if you are connected to Tracker A only and someone else is connected to Tracker B only, then you can't see each other; I believe you have to have a tracker in common.)

ZeroNet comes with a short list of trackers built-in, but some people have made longer, regularly-updated lists with more trackers. Some of these lists are made by Chinese ZeroNet users, I believe because the Chinese government blocks the addresses of known trackers, so Chinese ZeroNet users need these updating lists with additional trackers, with changing addresses, to avoid being blocked. (Using one of these lists involves trusting the producer of the list.)

There was a post on ZeroMe, in English and Chinese, with the address of one of these updating lists and the instructions for using it. I followed the instructions and now I have a lot more trackers to connect to (currently my ZeroHello reports: ***TRACKERS: 52/68***). And because I guess a lot of other people using this list and connecting to the trackers in it are in China (who are blocked from the regular trackers), I suppose I see a lot more peers in China than you.

If you're interested in this using this list, I'm afraid I can't find the ZeroMe post (I believe I found it via a different post by user @ssdifnskdjfnsdjk: ) and I can't remember the exact instructions but the following *might* work.

1. Visit [BT高清电影网](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1JuwWYEgApiBVNyGxhvNYyohsv4YMtxy7M) (this is a Chinese ZeroNet site for BitTorrent sharing which also produces the tracker list). Visiting it will make you a peer of this site, allowing you to access its content, including the tracker list.
2. In [ZeroHello](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/), go to the three-dot menu and select ***Configuration***.
3. In the section ***Tracker files***, add the following:
`data/1JuwWYEgApiBVNyGxhvNYyohsv4YMtxy7M/trackers_all.txt`
4. In the section ***Proxy for tracker connections***, select `Disable`.

Every now and then, at least for the first few weeks after doing this, I'd would find it impossible to browse ZeroNet. So I would check ***ZeroHello > Configuration*** and find that ***Proxy for tracker connections*** was on `Tor`. I would set it back to `Disable` and then everything would work fine again.

Just in case, I'll give a couple other of my settings in ***ZeroHello > Configuration*** (I can't remember if they're relevant or not):
+ ***Tor***: Enable
+ ***Use Tor bridges***: On

@xcape2net:
I am not an expert :) so be careful about anything I say here.
+ Tracker number: My guess is that the second number is the total number of active trackers my peer is aware of, thanks mainly to the tracker list I use.
+ File server port: sorry, I don't know.
+ Master list: if anyone can download and run the tracker software (and modify it even, as it's open source), then a complete master list might not be possible. I guess the closest we can come are these updated user-created lists like the one I'm using.
+ P2P: Like BitTorrent (which it's based on) ZeroNet ***is*** peer-to-peer, in the sense that the content (zites, images, videos etc) travels directly between peers and ***not*** up to/down from servers. But it's not a ***fully  decentralized*** peer-to-peer network, because (like original BitTorrent) it still requires trackers in order for peers to find each other and their content.
People often suggest using a [Distributed Hash Table](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_hash_table) (DHT) instead of trackers, just like BitTorrent now also has. But I believe there's a complication: hashes are good for locating ***unchanging*** content (e.g. a video published on ZeroNet or shared on BitTorrent) but not necessarily for ***changing*** content (e.g. a website on ZeroNet whose articles are edited/updated). When the content changes, the hash changes, rendering the hash in the DHT useless. I believe a practical, fully-decentralized solution for finding ***changing*** content via something like DHT still needs to be found and/or implemented.
I'm not sure but this issue of depending on trackers vs. DHT might be addressed in the upcoming version of ZeroNet created with the Python3 programming language, which will allow new features compared to the current version of ZeroNet built in Python2. Hopefully someone who knows more can answer that.
